By not stopping what's happening is making people leave...

It's either pis=
s off a few people who refuse to adapt their play style or let the game die=
 since all the characters grow stagnate doing nothing but repeating what th=
ey themselves or someone else has done previously.

Regardless of what happ=
ens some people will grumble, some will leave but by changing one ensures t=
he game survives so players that leave can be replaced.

Basically  a damne=
d if you do damned if you don't scenario.
  ----- Original Message ----- 
 =
 From: Legendarynemasis@... 
  To: nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Sund=
ay, January 20, 2002 2:29 PM
  Subject: Re: All Read: Important


  You rai=
se a great many good points, but ypu see the council wont do what your sugg=
esting. By stopping whats happening in NBWRPG will make the people unhappy =
and thats what the council does, it tries to keep them happy. It doesnt wan=
t them to live with the burden of living with the consequences with their c=
harachters actions as well as their own. This I pointed out earlier right b=
efore a good amount of players left. 

  In a message dated 1/20/2002 10:36=
:29 AM Eastern Standard Time, jhogan@... writes:



    Anywa=
y I was going to rant on about how a sequel wouldn't be all that
    differ=
ent from a restart but I figured why bother?

    When I hit the end of my =
long typed out rant I hit the problem. The real
    one. Another person pos=
ted that characters are not allowed to die
    currently...he is utterly in=
correct.

    The problem is the role-playing 101 aspect. People are given =
the
    responsibility to judge how much damage they take...however as we'v=
e seen
    some can't role-play their way out of a wet paper bag let alone =
responsibly
    judge how much damage their character takes. When a bot doe=
s get damaged
    what typically happens here?

    Here's the list:

    1=
) The enemy bot suddenly becomes cockeyed unable to hit the broad side of a=

    barn even if he was a g1 and standing over it.

    2) The bot never g=
ives chase to his prey. It always lets the long time
    character slip awa=
y.

    3) A short stay (a few hours usually) in the CR chamber and any dam=
age is
    completely gone.

    4) The character "dies" but faked his deat=
h coming back as an enemy
    infiltrator.

    5) Character "dies" but an =
evil clone appears which after various meeting
    with colleagues or "love=
d ones" turns good again. Personality reverts to
    pre-evil clone.

    6=
) Character "dies" but is reborn as a more powerful offspring. Personality
=
    is hardly different.

    7) Character "dies" but the players 6 other c=
haracters cart it's blasted
    carcass back to a lab where they resurrect =
him.

    8) Character "dies" replace with new bot same personality...event=
ually
    people will forget you died and you can go back to your old form.=


    Since most will never let their "favorite" character(s) die, I mean t=
ruly
    die, never come back like, there's really very little new plotline=
s you can
    do with them without repeating rehashed already done ones. Ta=
ke for example
    the geotrons planing to attack the new cat faction....bo=
th factions will
    survive, I doubt either player who controls the majori=
ty of bots in either
    faction is gonna let their characters get anywhere=
 near killed.

    And what's to stop this from happening if a restart/sequ=
el DOES occur? The
    role-playing by some will still stink, characters wi=
ll still be incapable of
    dying and given another year or so all plotlin=
es for THAT game will be
    starting to repeat. While I still do believe a=
 restart/sequel is in order I
    think the role-playing problem needs addr=
essing first to stop a repeat of
    what's happening to NBW.





  Your u=
se of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.
